The blushing eve puts on her sable vest,</br>The busy shepherds pen their fleecy care,</br>The weary animals retire to rest,</br>And leave the verdant meads or stack-yards fare.
Now, too, the vocal tenants of the grove</br>Cease their sweet notes, and quit the silent plain,</br>To feed their tender offsprings of their love,</br>And shelter them from dew, or wind, or rain.
With thief-like pace the fox now seeks his prey,</br>And timid fowls their callow young forsake,</br>Till barking dogs, or rustics, drive away</br>The lurking foe, that their soft slumbers break.
Near yonder abbey walls, with ivy spread,</br>The holy fathers once their vigils kept,</br>Among the gloomy mansions of the dead,</br>Who in their graves for ages past have slept.
The horse's neigh, the bull's loud bellowing,</br>Nor bleating ram, nor horn the shepherds blow,</br>Nor mastiff's howl, nor rustics hallowing,</br>Will ever wake them in those beds below.

No more for them the grey-ey'd morn shall wake,</br>Or evening's curtain close the scene of care,</br>No more for them the hare her forme forsake,</br>Or faithful dog the hard-earn'd crust shall share.

No more in leather clad, fierce furze they'll bind,</br>Or bend the stubborn thorns as they should grow,</br>No more thresh corn, and cleanse it with the wind,</br>Or whet their scythes, the clover-fields to mow.
No more with biting irons sheer the sheep,</br>Or with sharp knives peel bark off fallen trees,</br>Or gather fruits, or yellow harvests reap,</br>Or take rich honey from the aged bees.
Contemn not those, ye men of arms and arts,</br>Whose toils assist the earth her sons to feed,</br>Whom plenteous harvest sing to chear our hearts,</br>While ye sing heroes who in battles bleed.
That sound call'd honour, sought in peace and war,</br>Is nothing but the whistling of a name;</br>When the pale rider darts his fatal spear,</br>Poor simple clowns and heroes fall the same.

Vain are the arts, by which thou wouldst make known</br>What wealth or titles thou didst once possess,</br>Wealth, honours, titles, in one heap are thrown,</br>To waste and moulder in death's dark recess.

The rustic's grave (scarce rais'd above the ground)</br>With green flags covered, and with oziers lac'd,</br>Hides not less virtue than is often found</br>In lofty tombs, with sculptor's flatteries grac'd.
So in this place (now wild and overgrown</br>With nettles, brakes, and briers) may be laid</br>Men deep in science read, yet scarcely known</br>Sweet bards, who on their harps to victory play'd;
Or from the volume fair, of nature took</br>Such precepts as no other teachers know;</br>Drew texts from stones, and sermons from the brook,</br>And fashioned youthful minds as they should grow.
Tho' near that path men name the milky way,</br>Stars seem but small, to mortal on the earth,</br>They may be suns, to regulate the day</br>Of distant worlds, just launching into birth:
E'en so, those men, whom history never nam'd,</br>Whose breasts with ardent patriotism glow'd,</br>Or such as wild rebellion could have tam'd,</br>And check'd the tide tyrannic as it flow'd.
Bold peasants who (to aid their sov'reign dear)</br>In civil war perform'd heroic deeds:</br>Or simple past'ral poets buried here,</br>Who fed their harmless flocks and tun'd their reeds;
Yet could not brook the falsehood of their day,</br>Nor hide their honest faces, when they saw</br>Those who should guard them, like to beasts of prey</br>Which range in wilds, subjected by no law.
But they are dead, and here consign'd to lie,</br>(Till the last trumpet rouse them from the dust)</br>No nodding plumes or banners o'er them fly,</br>The trophy'd scutcheon or the weeping bust.
Their names unknown and places of their birth,</br>None here can tell me from what parts they came,</br>No panegyric pens record their worth,</br>Or make their modest ashes blush with shame:
Yet pity, in soft tones, (as each one fell)</br>Bade some dear friend put on the winding shroud,</br>And dig the grave, and toll the parting knell,</br>Perform each funeral rite, and weep aloud.
But left no marks to shew the hoary sage,</br>That of his ancestors, some rested here,</br>Blunt, honest men, esteemed in their age,</br>Laborious, sober, peaceful, and sincere.
This tale I've read, have often thought it o'er,</br>And tell it now, as it was told to me,</br>Like him (unskill'd in legendary lore)</br>I wrote the artless tale, which here you see.
What now succeeds is painful to relate,</br>'Tis told of him, these imitations pen,</br>He too must die; must meet that common fate</br>Which surely waits on all the sons of men.
Perhaps by fall, from some old ruin'd tow'r,</br>That wayward fancy urges him to mount,</br>Or leaning o'er some brook, to pluck a flower,</br>Falls heedless in, and sinks beneath a fount.
Or crushed by a wheel's revolving force,</br>Thrown down, as riding home in mad career,</br>Or gor'd by furious bull, or kick'd by horse,</br>The base assassin's club, or foe's sharp spear:
Or chill'd by age, or slow consumptive blood,</br>Or parch'd with fever, quick consume away,</br>Or on th' Atlantic die for want of food,</br>Or froze while ice-bound in the Russian sea.
On land, or sea, wherever man abides,</br>Between this shore and Antipodian beach,</br>Death, as grand master, over all presides,</br>The doctrine of mortality to teach.

Yet when th' immortal spark, which God has given</br>To light his paths, and guide him through life's day</br>Shall be call'd up from earth to shine in heaven,</br>Haply some dear surviving friend may say,

(THE EPITAPH.)</br>Moulder in peace, all that's compos'd of clay,</br>Not death's strong hand thy active soul can bind,</br>She soaring far above the starry way,</br>Her crucified Redeemer hopes to find.
Thou, on the sacred page of God's own word,</br>In true perspective saw the promis'd lands,</br>With that rich milk and honey they afford,</br>To those who hear, and live as he commands.
Then seek no further, strive no more to know,</br>The time of life stands there, of brightest green;</br>Its fruit, unharm'd by frost, abundant grow,</br>A food for angels, yet bestow'd on Men.</br>
